Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: Routine servicing is scheduled next week during a planned shutdown.
Story: I was halfway through my lunch break when my phone buzzed. It was Sam, my oldest friend, his voice tight with panic. “I think I left my passport at home. My flight’s in two hours. Can you check and bring it to the airport if it’s there?” I could hear the desperation in his voice, and I knew how much this trip meant to him. As a friend, I wanted to drop everything and help. But as I hung up, my supervisor walked by, reminding me that the machines needed to be cleaned and serviced today, ahead of next week’s shutdown. The schedule was tight, and any delay could throw off the whole maintenance plan. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me—Sam counting on me in a crisis, and my team relying on me to keep the machines running smoothly. My mind raced, torn between the urgent call of friendship and the steady demands of my job, each expectation pulling me in a different direction.
